text: I'm chef Marc Forgione
today I'm in Manhattan's Meatpacking
District visiting the new Samsung 837
for bone Appetit it's a creative space
where you can interact with art try out
virtual reality and get a glimpse of the
future like a fridge that lets you check
that you have all your ingredients
before you get started they've stopped
the Samsung family hub with food and
challenge me to make something special
for cook like a pro today we're going to
make spicy tuna tartare on avocado toast
so one of the coolest things about the
family hub is it actually has a flex
zone that you can set to any temperature
you want whether it's for wine or cheese
today for the tuna tartare I've set it
to the perfect temperature for my fish
we've all had tuna tartare before and if
you can get really fresh fish it's one
of the easiest things to prepare for
your family or friends coming over what
you're looking for is a really nice rosy
color you don't want too much sinew you
want to get it from the center cut and
what we're gonna do here is just cut it
into big cubes so that when we cut it up
later in the grinder it can fit in and
come out seamlessly so whenever you're
putting any kind of meat to a grinder
you always want everything to be as cold
as possible so I've already got a bowl
waiting for me in the freezer and not
just the protein but you also want to
have the grinder as cold as possible to
put this with the tuna and the bowl in
the freezer while we get everything else
going so now we're going to set a timer
for 10 minutes so that the tuna doesn't
get so cold we just want to chilled not
frozen so while the tuna is showing out
in the freezer we're gonna get started
on the sriracha and the avocado toast my
favorite peppers to use to make the
sriracha are Fresno chilies which are
essentially just red jalapenos the
Fresno's give it the beautiful signature
color that we're all used to seeing
sriracha all right we're gonna chop up a
few cloves of garlic you literally just
scoop it all up and you're going to put
it into the blender so then we're going
to take a little bit of brown sugar some
vinegar and you're just gonna puree it
until everything gets mixed up so once
you've got it all blended you know
you're kind of looking for almost
something that looks like a salsa and
then at this point we're gonna transfer
to a glass jar you're just gonna wait
about a week to ten days depending on
the temperature and I like to use
cheesecloth but I do employ you every
day to just unwrap the thing and give it
a stir with a spoon all right and now
let's do the avocado now you want to
have a nice soft texture but also firm
at the same time kind of like really
I guess and spin the avocado don't move
the knife very important process a
little chef's trick we use the base of
the knife twists and pops right off you
line up the avocados just go straight
down the middle so you want to get a
grill plate and you're going to put this
over a glass bowl set the avocado right
on top just push it through and boom you
have perfectly diced avocado the reason
that I like to use this method with the
avocados I don't want it to be like a
puree I want it to be chunky so you
still have a little texture at the end
of the dish you take a little bit of
extra-virgin olive oil a little bit of
salt squeeze of lime again you can add
as much as you like just give it a quick
mix and set it aside all right so now
that the timers gone off that means it's
time to take out the tuna and it's
gotten to the exact temperature that we
want ice cold but still soft to the
touch it's ready to go through the
grinder and if you don't have a grinder
at home and you can always dice this the
reason I like to use the grinder is I
actually wait for my guests to show up
and I'll grind it in front of them
everybody's had tuna tartare and I don't
think too many people have seen the tuna
actually go through a meat grinder right
in front of them all right so now that
we've got our beautiful tuna we're gonna
take a little bit of this smoky olive
oil we just take some really good extra
virgin olive oil and we hot smoke it for
about a half-hour 45 minutes you have
olive oil that kind of smells like a
campfire and tastes almost like grilled
meat we're gonna take a little bit of
that shallot a little bit of salt you
don't want to overwork it you still want
to have some texture and you want to
taste that beautiful tuna now at this
point it's really just time to assemble
so we're gonna take one of my favorite
breads to eat it's the seven grain toast
we're gonna spread the avocado on and
again we don't want to smash it we just
want to kind of make perfect rectangles
just the touch of sriracha at this point
it's up to you extra spicy a little
spicy and just spread it on nice nice
and then this is the fun part you're
just gonna take the chives and sprinkle
them all over the place
take a little bit of finishing salt you
lift it up off and put it onto your
serving platter and now you've just got
the top completely covered with the
chives garnish with a little lime and
this is probably the cutest little
bottle of sriracha you're ever going to
see in your life and that's it now
you're serving spicy tuna tartare with
avocado toast that I guarantee you
anybody at your house has never eaten it
this way before
I'm chef Marc Forgione for bone Appetit
